front.title: Use of Internationalized Email Addresses in EPP protocol

abstract.t: This document permits usage of Internationalized Email Addresses in the EPP protocol and specifies the terms when it can be used by EPP clients and servers. The Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP), being developed before appearing the standards for Internationalized Email Addresses (EAI), does not support such email addressed.
TO BE REMOVED on turning to RFC: The document is edited in the dedicated github repo. Please send your submissions via GitHub.

section.name: Introduction
section.t: RFC 6530 introduced the framework for Internationalized Email Addresses. To make such addresses more widely accepted, the changes to various protocols need to be introduced.

This document describes an Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) notification mechanism for indicatinf the support of Email Addresses Internationalized (EAI) in object mappings like the EPP contact mapping. The described mechanism can be applied to any EPP object mapping that uses an email address, where the EPP contact mapping is used in the examples.

The Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) specified in RFC 5730 is a base document for object management operations and an extensible framework that maps protocol operations to objects. The specifics of various objects managed via EPP is described in separate documents. This document is only referring to an email address as a property of a managed object, such as the <contact:email> element in the EPP contact mapping or the <org:email> element in the EPP organization mapping.
RFC 3735 provides a guideline to extend the EPP protocol for various purposes. This extension represents a Command-Response Extension.

This document describes an Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) extension for using the Email Addresses Internationalized (EAI) in an extension to EPP object mappings like the EPP contact mapping. The extension can be applied to any EPP object mapping that uses an email address, where the EPP contact mapping is used in the examples.

In this document we introduce the new mechanism designed to exchange the necessary information between peers. The extension uses the EPP greeting and EPP login services to signal a functional enhancement of all of the object-level extensions or command-response extensions that include an e-mail address field. It pretty much represents an override of the validation and storage of the email addresses with an extensible set of EPP objects and command-response extensions supported over an EPP session. There are no new EPP XML elements to flag or carry EAI values. This is broad, but I believe it would be simple and effective.

section.name: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

In examples, "C:" represents lines sent by a protocol client and "S:" represents lines returned by a protocol server. In examples, indentation and whitespace are provided only to illustrate element relationships and are not a required feature of this protocol.

"eai-0.1" is used as an abbreviation for "urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:epp:eai-0.1". The XML namespace prefix "eai" is used, but implementations MUST NOT depend on it. Instead, they are to employ a proper namespace-aware XML parser and serializer to interpret and output the XML documents.

section.name: Migrating to Newer Versions of This Extension
section.t: Servers that implement this extension SHOULD provide a way for clients to progressively update their implementations when a new version of the extension is deployed. A newer version of the extension is expected to use an XML namespace with a higher version number than the prior versions.

section.name: Indicating the support of EAI addresses
section.t: This document does not define new protocol but an operational practice using the existing EPP protocol, where the client and the server can signal support for the operational practice using a namespace URI in the login and greeting extension services. The namespace URI "eai-0.1" is used to signal support for the operational practice. The client includes the namespace URI in an <svcExtension> <extURI> element of the [RFC5730] <login> Command. The server includes the namespace URI in an <svcExtension> <extURI> element of the [RFC5730] Greeting.

If both client and server have indicated the support of the EAI addresses during the session establishment, it implies possibility to process the EAI address in any message having the email attribute during the established session.

If neither client nor server indicated the support of the EAI address, it implies that all the attributes email in the protocol message are compliant to the specifications describing the managed object.
The behaviour in case when one of the peers does not support the extension and the other does is defined below.

section.name: Email Address Specification
section.t: Email address syntax is defined in in RFC 6530. This mapping does not prescribe minimum or maximum lengths for character strings used to represent email addresses.

section.name: EPP commands mapping
section.t: A detailed description of the EPP syntax and semantics can be found in the EPP core protocol specification .

section.name: EPP Query Commands
section.t: EPP provides three commands to retrieve object information: <check> to determine if an object is known to the server, <info> to retrieve detailed information associated with an object, and <transfer> to retrieve object transfer status information.

section.name: EPP <check> Command
section.t: This extension does not add any elements to the EPP <check> command or <check> response described in the .

section.name: EPP <info> command
section.t: This extension does not define additional elements to extend the EPP <info> command of an EPP object mapping, but, being supported by both peers, allows using the EAI address in the response.

If the query was successful, the server replies with the regular EPP <resData>. If both peers include the "eai-0.1" XML namespace in the login services, the EAI email address is set as the email attribute using the create command or update command, then the EPP object mapping email element SHOULD be included in the response with the email address value.
Example <info> response for the authorized client:

section.name: EPP <transfer> Command
section.t: This extension does not add any elements to the EPP <transfer> query command or <transfer> response described in the .

section.name: EPP Transform Commands
section.t: EPP provides five commands to transform objects: <create> to create an instance of an object, <delete> to delete an instance of an object, <renew> to extend the validity period of an object, <transfer> to manage object sponsorship changes, and <update> to change information associated with an object.

section.name: EPP <create> command
section.t: This extension allows using the EAI email addresses in the EPP <create> command of an object mapping like the EPP contact mapping

The EPP <create> command provides a transform operation that allows a client to create an object. This extension does not define additional elements to extend the EPP <create> command of an EPP object mapping, but, being supported by both peers, allows using the EAI address in the request.
Example <create> command:

section.t: The EPP <update> command provides a transform operation that allows a client to update an object. This extension does not define additional elements to extend the EPP <update> command of an EPP object mapping, but, being supported by both peers, allows using the EAI address in the request.
Example <update> command:

Security Considerations
section.t: Registries SHOULD validate the domain names in the provided email addresses. This can be done by validating all code points according to IDNA2008 .

section.name: Implementation Considerations
section.t: Registries MAY apply extra limitation to the email address syntax (e.g. the addresses can be limited to Left-to-Right scripts). These limitations are out of scope of this document.

front.title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

abstract.t: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.

front.title: Guidelines for Extending the Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP)

abstract.t: The Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) is an application layer client-server protocol for the provisioning and management of objects stored in a shared central repository. Specified in XML, the protocol defines generic object management operations and an extensible framework that maps protocol operations to objects. This document presents guidelines for use of EPP's extension mechanisms to define new features and object management capabilities. This memo provides information for the Internet community.

This document describes an application-layer client-server protocol for the provisioning and management of objects stored in a shared central repository. Specified in XML, the protocol defines generic object management operations and an extensible framework that maps protocol operations to objects. This document includes a protocol specification, an object mapping template, and an XML media type registration. This document obsoletes RFC 4930. [STANDARDS-TRACK]

This document describes an Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) mapping for the provisioning and management of individual or organizational social information identifiers (known as "contacts") stored in a shared central repository. Specified in Extensible Markup Language (XML), the mapping defines EPP command syntax and semantics as applied to contacts. This document obsoletes RFC 4933. [STANDARDS-TRACK]

front.title: Overview and Framework for Internationalized Email

abstract.t: Full use of electronic mail throughout the world requires that (subject to other constraints) people be able to use close variations on their own names (written correctly in their own languages and scripts) as mailbox names in email addresses. This document introduces a series of specifications that define mechanisms and protocol extensions needed to fully support internationalized email addresses. These changes include an SMTP extension and extension of email header syntax to accommodate UTF-8 data. The document set also includes discussion of key assumptions and issues in deploying fully internationalized email. This document is a replacement for RFC 4952; it reflects additional issues identified since that document was published. [STANDARDS-TRACK]

front.title: Extension Registry for the Extensible Provisioning Protocol

abstract.t: The Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) includes features to add functionality by extending the protocol. It does not, however, describe how those extensions are managed. This document describes a procedure for the registration and management of extensions to EPP, and it specifies a format for an IANA registry to record those extensions.

front.title: Ambiguity of Uppercase vs Lowercase in RFC 2119 Key Words

abstract.t: RFC 2119 specifies common key words that may be used in protocol specifications. This document aims to reduce the ambiguity by clarifying that only UPPERCASE usage of the key words have the defined special meanings.

front.title: The Unicode Code Points and Internationalized Domain Names for Applications (IDNA)

abstract.t: This document specifies rules for deciding whether a code point, considered in isolation or in context, is a candidate for inclusion in an Internationalized Domain Name (IDN).
It is part of the specification of Internationalizing Domain Names in Applications 2008 (IDNA2008). [STANDARDS-TRACK]
